newsitem.title: USA: Minn. gov vetoes $6.7 bln education funding bill.
newsitem.headline: Minn. gov vetoes $6.7 bln education funding bill.

text.p: Minnesota Gov. Arne Carlson on Tuesday vetoed a $6.7 billion elementary and secondary education spending package that lacked tuition tax credits he had proposed.

Carlson, a Republican, called the credits a key ingredient for parents that would lead to increased competition and school reforms in a letter to Democratic House Speaker Phil Carruthers announcing the veto.

The governor's veto will require lawmakers to return for a special session to resolve the impasse. No date has been set for that special session and Carlson and lawmakers have not yet scheduled a meeting to discuss an agenda for it, spokesman Brian Dietz said.

Carlson said lawmakers included a number of "commendable" reforms in the bill forwarded to him, but without his $150 million tax credit plan "it does not achieve this administration's fundamental goal of reforming the education system and allowing choices for all Minnesota families."
On Friday, Carruthers had urged Carlson to sign the bill, contending that failure to adopt a full budget by July 1 could jeopardize Minnesota's efforts to obtain a AAA bond rating.
In his response Tuesday, Carlson wrote that Minnesota has reached a $2.3 billion surplus largely due to vetoes he has cast, placing the state in position to completely restore its AAA bond rating.
